reasoning: The critique targets a relatively narrow part of the essay: the discussion of digital beings and the idea that “getting rights right”/delaying deployment is a safe hedge. Even if fully accepted, it wouldn’t undermine the core “no easy eutopia” thesis (indeed it arguably adds another way eutopia is fragile), so centrality is low. As a refutation, it’s also limited: it points to a plausible regulatory second‑order effect (displacement to black markets) but doesn’t show the essay actually relies on the allegedly broken assumption or recommends a status-first pause. The mechanism is reasonably coherent and clearly stated. However, it is framed as a concrete 2030–2034 historical narrative, which (given today’s date) is not correct as stated; treating it charitably as a hypothetical raises plausibility, but the factual dressing lowers correctness. Little of the text is fluff, and it stays tightly on one issue.
title: Status-first digital rights delays can drive black markets and worsen safety and abuse
